column1: #Text=Jim Murphy announces resignation as Scottish Labour Party leader
#Text=Jim Murphy yesterday announced he intends to stand down as Scottish Labour Party leader next month , after narrowly surviving a no confidence vote .

#Text=Murphy said he will present a list of suggested reforms to be made to the party , including changing the system for electing party leader to one member , one vote , upon offering his resignation at the next meeting of its national executive in June .
#Text=Murphy also said he will not stand for the Scottish Parliament election in May 2016 and will " do something else " .
#Text=At a meeting in the Scottish city Glasgow yesterday , the party 's national executive held a vote of no confidence in Murphy ; he won by 17 votes to 14 .
#Text=" Today I received more support in the executive vote than I did from members of the executive when I stood for election five months ago " , Murphy said .
#Text=Murphy became Scottish Labour leader in December 2014 , following Johann Lamont 's resignation from the role .

#Text=Until Scottish Labour holds a fresh leadership election — its sixth in a span of eight years — Kezia Dugdale , currently the party 's deputy leader , is to assume the role of acting leader for the time being .
#Text=Murphy cited concerns about Scottish Labour being divided as a contributory factor to his decision .
#Text=" Scotland needs a strong Labour party ;

#Text= Whether in Scotland , or in the contest to come across the UK , we cannot have our leaders selected or deselected by the grudges and grievances of one prominent man .

#Text=Harvie said Murphy 's resignation was  almost inevitable , but even as he announced it he promised to further weaken Labour ’s relationship with the wider labour movement .

#Text=Scottish Conservative Party leader Ruth Davidson tweeted :  Jim Murphy announces a managed exit in order to help the party , which is to his credit .
